title: 113_s1723
content: The Act may be cited as the "No Obamacare Kickbacks Act of 2013". The Congress finds that the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act applies civil penalties for violations of the False Claims Act to kickbacks involving Federal health care programs. The Center for Consumer Information & Insurance Oversight stated that the Department of Health and Human Services has broad authority to regulate the Federal and State Marketplaces. The CCIIO suggests that qualified health plans under the Affordable Care Act are similar to Medicare Advantage plans in terms of regulatory authority and receiving Federal dollars. The Federal Government facilitates applications and enrollment in qualified health plans through federally-funded call centers, web portals, and consumer assistance personnel, similar to how it is done for Medicare Advantage and Prescription Drug Benefit programs. Health care programs involving Federal programs can result in penalties under the Social Security Act and False Claims Act. The amendment clarifies the application of anti-kickback laws to qualified health plans, marketplaces, and programs under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. It includes plans funded under specific subtitles of the Act and related programs. The amendment is retroactively effective to the enactment of the Act. The amendment clarifies the application of anti-kickback laws to qualified health plans, marketplaces, and programs under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. It includes plans funded under specific subtitles of the Act and related programs. The amendment is retroactively effective to the enactment of the Act. HHS OIG and GAO will conduct a joint study and report. The Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services and the Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the impact of anti-kickback laws on qualified health plans, marketplaces, and programs under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. They will identify relevant plans and entities benefiting from these laws. The Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services and the Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the impact of anti-kickback laws on qualified health plans, marketplaces, and programs under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. They will identify entities benefiting from these laws and estimate the impact of excluding certain plans and programs from the definition of "Federal health care program". The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act will be excluded from the definition of "Federal health care program" under section 1128B(f) of the Social Security Act. A report will be submitted to Congress one year after enactment, detailing the impact of this exclusion on health care premiums, consumer choice in insurance coverage, drug use, and the net cost of the Act to the Federal Government and all States and territories. The Inspector General and Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for legislative or administrative action based on specified information in subsection (a).
